question: 6 (b)
sols_html:
Recall the definition of the eigenvalue, we know that \(-i\) is one of Q\(^{\prime}\)s eigenvalues when \(det(Q+iI)=0\), and \(Q+iI\) is invertible if and only if \(det(Q+iI)\neq 0\). From part a, we know that Q is a symmetric matrix. A symmetric matrix will only have real eigenvalues and since \(-i\) is not real, it is not an eigenvalue of Q and \(det(Q+iI)\) is never equal to zero.

Therefore, the matrix \(Q+iI\) is invertible.

statement_html:
Let u be a unit vector and Q = I - 2uuT. Show:

(b) The matrix Q + iI is invertible.
